title: Private Equity Daily: Investors Focus on Rising PE Costs | AMC's Ape Year | Blackstone in Talks to Buy Manhattan Property; Private equity has long been one of the most expensive asset classes and it's not getting any cheaper
text:
Today's Top Stories

Private-equity has long been one of the most expensive asset classes and as WSJ Pro Private Equity's Preeti Singh writes, it's not getting any cheaper. The costs of forming private-equity funds are rising and investors are also being asked to foot the bill for certain expenses that historically were covered by fund managers, according to a recent report from the Institutional Limited Partners Association, a trade organization for investors in private-markets funds.

A mob rescued the world's largest movie-theater chain from the edge of bankruptcy. As Alexander Gladstone and Erich Schwartzel write for The Wall Street Journal, it turned out to be only the first act in an improbable story that made this year in American business like none other. More than four million people joined forces to put billions of dollars into AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc., staking their money on a company so battered by the pandemic and competition from streaming entertainment that Wall Street investors had bet big on its imminent collapse.

Blackstone Inc. is in advanced talks to acquire a 49% stake in a new Manhattan office tower in a deal that values the skyscraper at $2.85 billion, providing a shot of confidence for New York during tough times, Peter Grant writes for The Wall Street Journal. A venture led by Brookfield Asset Management could reach an agreement to sell the stake in the One Manhattan West property to Blackstone in the next few days, said people familiar with the matter.

Big Number

$250 Billion

How much firms pitching funds with targets of more than $5 billion are projected to raise in 2022, according to PitchBook Data Inc.

Deals

Technology focused private-equity firm Thoma Bravo has agreed to acquire publicly traded financial technology company Bottom line Technologies Inc. in a deal that values the company at $2.6 billion. The deal is the latest acquisition of a public company that the firm has backed in recent years. Earlier this year, the firm acquired manufacturing and supply chain software provider QAD Inc. for around $2 billion and ecommerce shipping solutions provider Stamps.com for around $6.6 billion. Portsmouth, N.H.-based Bottom line offers technology that facilitates business-to-business tasks such as payment processing, cash management, bill review, fraud detection, regulatory compliance and behavioral analytics.

KKR & Co. has agreed to acquire Japanese financial and accounting software provider Yayoi Co. Ltd. from financial services group ORIX Corporation, which has backed Yayoi since 2014. KKR said it is backing the deal out of its KKR Asian Fund IV, a $15 billion pool that closed earlier this year.

SK Capital Partners has acquired a majority stake in pharmaceutical solutions and specialty ingredients company SEQENS, investing alongside Bpifrance, Nov Santé, Mérieux Equity Partners, Ardian, Eximium and the company's management team. Concurrent with the deal, SEQENS merged with another SK Capital portfolio company, Wavelength Pharmaceuticals, which also manufactures and develops active pharmaceutical ingredients. According to the deal announcement, SEQENS had revenue of €1.1 billion, equivalent to $1.25 billion, and employs 3,200 across 3 continents.

Apollo Global Management has completed its acquisition of Kem One Group, a leading European producer of polyvinyl chloride, caustic soda, and chlorinated derivatives, from De Krassny GmbH. Apollo said Kem One would pursue a growth strategy and execute plans to modernize its production footprint. Kem One has nearly 1,400 employees, divided between its industrial sites, its R&D laboratories, its sales offices in Europe, and its head office in Lyon, France.

Level Equity has backed a growth investment in SchoolPass Inc., a cloud-based software provider that helps schools manage attendance, campus movement, and campus wellness.

GrowthCurve Capital, a private-equity firm founded by Sumit Rajpal, the former global co-head of the merchant banking division of Goldman Sachs Group, has taken a majority stake in Brightway Insurance, a property and casualty insurance distribution company. Mark Cantin, an operating executive at GrowthCurve, will become the new president and chief executive of Brightway, according to a press release.

Valeas Capital Partners, a new investment firm led by two former executives from Hellman & Friedman LLC, has led a $70 million funding round for Well Dot Inc., a consumer focused health improvement technology platform. The company previously raised a $40 million funding round last year and a $25 million round in 2018, according to a press release.

SPAC Track

Mondee Inc. is close to a deal with special-purpose acquisition company ITHAX Acquisition Corp. that would value the travel-technology firm at about $1 billion and take it public, Amrith Ramkumar writes for the Journal, citing people familiar with the matter. As part of its deal, Mondee would be expected to raise a $50 million private investment in public equity, or PIPE, featuring funds affiliated with Morgan Stanley Investment Management and other investors, the people said.

Nauticus Robotics Inc. is combining with a blank-check company in a deal that would take the ocean-task-automation firm public at a valuation of about $560 million, company officials said. As Amrith Ramkumar writes for the Journal, Nauticus is merging with CleanTech Acquisition Corp., a special-purpose acquisition company.

Exits

Clayton Dubilier & Rice said it is exiting a portion of its stake in Belron in a deal that values the auto glass repair and replacement company at €21 billion, the equivalent of $23.79 billion, roughly 7-times the company's €3 billion valuation when the private-equity firm bought an initial 40% stake in 2018. CD&R is selling around 39% of its fund's stake in the company to fellow private-equity investors Hellman & Friedman LLC and BlackRock Private Equity Partners. At the same time, CD&R sold the remaining 61% of its stake to a fund called CD&R Value Building Partners I LP and related vehicles, along with new special purpose vehicles created to continue the firm's ownership in Belron. CDR said investment vehicles managed by the firm would hold a 20% stake in Belron and remain the company's largest shareholder.

An affiliate of Carlyle Group said it has agreed to sell its stake in Japanese contract manufacturer of nutrition and pharmaceutical products Sunsho Pharmaceutical Co. Ltd. to Towa Pharmaceutical Co. Ltd., which specializes in research and development, production and marketing of generic drugs. The private-equity firm initially acquired Sunsho back in 2014 through its Carlyle Japan Partners III fund, according to a press release. Sunsho is among Japan's largest contract manufacturers for soft capsules and seamless capsules, the release stated.

Funds

Brookfield raised $4 billion for its latest flagship real-estate debt fund, Brookfield Real Estate Finance Fund VI, exceeding its initial target by $1 billion. Brookfield invested $400 million in BREF VI along with close to 50 limited partners, including private and public pension funds, labor organizations, endowments and insurance companies. The fund is focused on high-quality real estate assets in major U.S. metropolitan markets, and selectively in Europe and the U.K. The Fund has closed on 15 investments, representing aggregate mezzanine lending commitments of more than $700 million, to date.

Industry News

Pennsylvania Public School Employees' Retirement System's deputy chief investment officer Charles "Charlie" Spiller is the latest senior executive to retire from the beleaguered pension system, according to an email from the system. Mr. Spiller, who served for over 24 years at the pension, led its nontraditional investments portfolio, which includes private-equity. Under Mr. Spiller, PSERS' private assets grew from $1 billion to $29 billion and the team grew to 15 professionals from 4 investment professionals in 1997. Mr. Spiller is at least the third senior executive to announce his retirement from the pension this year. Last month, James Grossman, the pension's chief investment officer and Glen Grell, its executive director announced their retirements.

A coalition of large multinational companies has launched a late lobbying blitz to delay a tax increase on foreign earnings in the Build Back Better plan, saying it would hurt U.S. businesses when they compete with foreign rivals, Ted Mann and Brody Mullins report for the Journal. The dispute represents another potential stumbling block for President Biden's top domestic-policy priority, which relies on corporate tax increases to fund greater spending on education, child care, healthcare and other domestic programs.
